intro: Heracleum ceretanum, commonly known as the lesser cow parsley, is a biennial or short-lived perennial plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its umbellate inflorescence and aromatic compounds. The plant typically grows to a height of 60–120 cm, with finely divided, fern-like leaves and small white or greenish flowers. It thrives in disturbed soils and open habitats, often found along roadsides and in meadows. Its foliage and roots contain compounds that can be toxic to livestock, making it a plant of both ecological and cautionary interest.
